subtitle: Marcus Aurelius was the emperor of Rome from 161 to 180 AD and is considered as the last
of the Five Good Emperors. Widely referred to as a philanthropic ‘philosopher-king’,
Marcus throughout his life worked to embody the philosophy of Stoicism. Stoicism helped
him to be constantly mindful of his thoughts and actions. The ancient Stoics referred to
this practise as ‘prosochê’. It means always being vigilant about what you are thinking
and about what you do so that you can be fully cognizant of your choices and actively work
to make the most virtuous choice possible. During his rule, Aurelius constructed a series
of autobiographical writings known as the Meditations. In his meditations, he spends
a great deal of time emphasising the value of mindfulness and which is why in this video
we bring you 5 ways we could learn to be more mindful of our thoughts and actions from the
wisdom of Marcus Aurelius. Keep your focus on the present
Marcus Aurelius says “Each man only lives in this present instant…all the rest either
has been lived or remains in uncertainty.” One of the most basic principles of mindfulness
is the need to keep your mind on the current moment. When we think about the future, we
may feel worried or stressed. When we think about the past, we might feel sad or regret
the decisions that we made. It is only by living in the present moment that we can free
ourselves from these negative emotions and enjoy a more harmonious mindset.
Aurelius takes this a step further. It is not enough to have your mind focused on your
current experience. You should aim to cultivate an attitude of compassion and dignity in everything
you do. It is by being your best self that you set yourself up for success. If you know
that you have truly done your best, you will have no regrets when you look back. Where
ancient Stoic mindfulness differs from contemporary mindfulness practices is that while modern
mindfulness places a high value on breathing and meditation exercises, the ancients were
more concerned with being aware of their value-judgments and remembering to keep their focus on where
it could be most useful. It is interesting to note that we never worry
about the past. This is because the element of uncertainty is removed. However, we find
ourselves reliving those experiences, regretting what we could have done differently or wishing
there had been a different outcome. We let ourselves become obsessed with the past, which
isn’t helpful. It can’t change anything. All we can do is accept our past and move
forward. There can also be problems if you’re focused too much on the uncertainty of the
future. Worry is an emotion reserved solely for the future, which may bring us good or
bad experiences and when we don’t know which it will be, we find ourselves stressing about
it. Your stress isn’t helpful. It won’t change anything either. The only way you can
influence the future is by working in the present and making choices and decisions which
will take you closer to where you want to be.
There are a number of simple ways in which you can incorporate mindfulness into your
daily life. For example, you could decide on an intention which represents your new
mindful approach, such as ‘Appreciate every moment as it comes.’ Write it down and put
it somewhere you will see it often - or even put your intention in a number of different
places so you have regular reminders. Start your day with a reminder to be mindful. Say
your intention out loud and sit with it for a moment, considering how you will embody
it that day. You might like some light meditation practices like performing simple breathing
exercises, where you focus your attention on your breath for a few minutes. Check in
with yourself at regular intervals throughout the day. You might also like to be mindful
when you eat, focusing on every single bite and how the food tastes and feels in your
mouth. Be mindful when you have a shower, considering how the water feels cascading
over your body, the smell of your soap, the sound of the shower. The most mundane activities
can be magical if you are mindful of them. Just as you started your day with the intention
of being mindful, take a moment to sit and reflect at the end of the day as well. Look
back and see where you were mindful and embodied your intention and where you could have done
more. Celebrate your wins and think about how you can be even more mindful tomorrow.
Always choose to be your best self Marcus Aurelius tells us to “Waste no more
time arguing about what a good man should be. Be one.”
An important Stoic principle is the notion of living a virtuous life. Being virtuous
is an ongoing process, something which never ends because we should always be striving
to be our best self. For the Stoics, living a virtuous life wasn’t just about being
your best self; they felt that if everyone chose to be virtuous, together, they could
build a better society, a community of people who are working together for the common good
to create an environment which is positive for everyone involved.
Everything that happens to you is an opportunity for you to choose a virtuous response. It
doesn’t matter how painful, frightening, or difficult your situation is, if you react
with virtue, its inevitable outcome would be all those things which are so important
to us all like happiness, fulfilment, success, honour, love and reputation. Choosing to be
your best self is a continuous process. You should make a point of checking in with yourself
mentally throughout the day to see where your mind is focused. Ask yourself, are you distracted
by external influences? Are you being selfish instead of thinking about how you can best
serve those around you? When you become more aware of your thoughts on an ongoing basis,
you can take active action to channel them in the most beneficial direction for both
yourself and the people around you. There are some simple techniques you can use
to start actively working towards becoming your best self. For example, think about an
argument or disagreement you were recently caught up in. Create a mind map of the situation
being as objective as possible, examine your own motives and behavior. What did you do
wrong? What might you have done differently? What were your reasons for behaving the way
you did? What other explanations might there be? Could you have been kinder or more Stoic
in your approach? Now do the same for the other person. Put
yourself in their shoes and think about possible reasons for why they did what they did. What
factors might be involved that you don’t know about? Could there be anything happening
in their life which might explain their behavior? When you have done this, pick the kindest
explanation you have for the other person’s behavior and counter this with the harshest
explanation for yours. How does this change how you view what happened? Would you behave
differently in the future? The more conscious you can be about the way you choose to act
and feel, the more mindful you will be and the more control you can have over being the
best possible version of yourself. Another exercise you might like to try is
to write out a description of someone you know who you admire. Why do you look up to
them? What is it about them that makes them worthy of respect? What character traits of
theirs would you like to possess? Now do a description of yourself at your best. Think
about the qualities you have, not the qualities you think you ought to have. How is that person
different to who you are right now? How would you treat other people if you were that person?
How would your life change if you were always your best self? Everyday, sit down in the
evening and journal about your day. First write out what happened and then write out
what would have happened if your best self had experienced that same day. Continue to
do this until you only have one version of your day to journal because you were genuinely
at your best all the time.Being conscious about your actions and thoughts so that you
actively choose to be your best is the very epitome of mindfulness and will improve the
quality of your life immeasurably. Always do the right thing
To quote Marcus Aurelius “We ought to do good to others as simply as a horse runs,
or a bee makes honey, or a vine bears grapes season after season without thinking of the
grapes it has borne.” The ancient Stoics turned to nature for inspiration
and believed that humans were designed by nature to live in harmony with each other.
Aurelius used a lot of natural imagery in his writing to illustrate his point, in this
instance to demonstrate that we should not allow ourselves to become smug, arrogant,
or proud of our achievements. Marcus Aurelius ruled Rome during a period
of great conflict. After every major military victory, a so-called ‘triumph’ would be
held in Rome, which was a ceremonial procession meant to celebrate victorious generals who
would be driven through the city in a horse drawn chariot. Throughout the triumph,behind
the victorious general in the chariot stood a slave, holding a golden crown over his head.
One of the most interesting parts of this triumph was that this slave would also whisper
to the general “Remember you are mortal,” a timely reminder that while this moment might
be glorious, it could all be gone in an instant. Marcus Aurelius believed that we all should
keep a sense of humility, no matter how glorious our achievements might be. We are all mortals,
living for just a brief moment on this Earth. The consciousness of death’s reality can
help us keep things in an appropriate perspective, can teach us to be more compassionate towards
other people, can teach us to be just, as well as merciful.
We can implement this wisdom in our lives by avoiding being too arrogant, and by trying
to do the right thing at any given moment, being righteous in the relationships with
everybody around us. To do so, we should look deep inside our hearts, examine any negative
pattern by which we sometimes act, then take a step back and learn how to pause before
acting on anything. Oftentimes these negative patterns are born in fear of something like
the fear of being alone, fear of poverty, fear of not being enough and, ultimately,
the biggest of them all - the fear of death. To the Stoics, such fears were pointless.
We cannot control the actions of others or prevent the inevitable cycle of change. Therefore,
it is a waste of energy and time to fear that which you cannot control. If you face your
fears with courage and accept that not everything will go according to plan, you will be better
placed to cope with things that don't go your way. By overcoming these fears, our spirit
will free itself, we would become more open to others, more compassionate, as well as
more forgiving to ourselves and others. For example, if you are asked to do something
at work you consider immoral, say ditching a colleague and making him lose the job, in
spite of his high level skills, you should take a step back, reflect on what would be
the right action for you in this situation, confront your boss, and give a complete list
of reasons for why you think this action would be inappropriate. Your boss might get angry
at you for disobeying him, but, if you know you are on the right side of the situation,
then his anger would not matter for you. It is much more important to live life with a
clean conscience than to compromise your values for something so small in the grand scheme
of things. In this example, the fear you had to confront was your fear of losing your job
by making your boss angry and the negative pattern which you have to stop letting control
your life is the pattern of pleasing other people who do not deserve it.
4. Accept and love your life through good times and bad
In the words of Marcus Aurelius ‘It is my bad luck that this has happened to me.’
No, you should rather say: ‘It is my good luck…I can bear it without pain, neither
crushed by the present nor fearful of the future.’”
The Stoics were renowned for their ability to face even the toughest times with resilience
and acceptance. They actively cultivated hardship as a matter of course so that when the tough
times hit, they would be prepared to deal with it. This acceptance of fate can be described
as ‘amor fati.’ ‘Amor Fati’ means that whatever happens to you, if you have
the right state of being, you can take that experience and use it to shape you into an
even better person, regardless of whether it is positive or negative. As Aurelius put
it, “a blazing fire makes flame and brightness out of everything that is thrown into it.”
Even though we have different religious or spiritual backgrounds, we are all part of
something bigger than ourselves. Whatever you’ve done, whoever you are, your journey
has brought you to this place at this time. You are exactly where you need to be, so you
should appreciate and be thankful for this moment, regardless of whether it is currently
positive or negative. When you resent, regret, or resist what we’re
currently experiencing, you are fighting against your life, which will only bring you more
conflict. If you are able to accept and embrace whatever comes your way and start to live
in alignment with your life, everything becomes easier.This does not mean that you simply
passively accept other people mistreating you or become a victim of your circumstance.
It means to be completely present in the knowledge of who you are, and how you can be your best
self in any given situation. This is key to making the most of anything life throws at
you. When we are mindful, we develop the ability to live our lives unapologetically and cope
with whatever comes our way with strength, grace, and resilience.
The Stoics believed that one could only consider oneself a truly virtuous person if they had
full control over their thoughts, emotions, and actions. If you haven’t done something
wrong, why are you stressing about it? And if you have, why are you beating yourself
up about it instead of actively working to do better now and in the future? Whatever
problems you are dealing with right now, they’re not going to last forever and we would do
well to put things into perspective. You may think that you are a slave to your feelings,
incapable of controlling your emotional state, but in fact it is not external forces that
make you feel anything but your reaction to those forces that generate those feelings.
It is entirely up to you to decide how you’re going to feel about something. Ask yourself:
What can I hear? What can I smell? What can I taste? What can I touch? What can I see?
Work through each of your senses, taking a minute or two to fully focus on each and ground
yourself in the present. When you switch your attention to nothing but your literal experience
at that very second, it becomes easier to change your emotional response, or at least
tone down overwhelming feelings. Once you’ve done this a few times, you’ll see for yourself
how easy it is to reclaim your power so that you are no longer at the mercy of external
forces. And the more you continue to do this, the easier it becomes.
5. Change your thoughts to change your life In our final quote for this video, Marcus
Aurelius tells us “You have power over your mind — not outside events. Realize this,
and you will find strength.” The Stoics held that their thoughts were the
ultimate arbiter of the nature of the reality they experienced. They understood that if
they were pessimistic, they would only ever see the negative things in life, even if they
were rich and successful. Conversely, if they found a reason to be grateful for every experience,
regardless of these experiences being positive or negative, they would be able to find happiness
and blessings in the moment. There has been a lot of research into the
placebo effect which has conclusively demonstrated that the way we think has a direct effect
on our experience. For example, studies have shown that telling people that they were drinking
something laden with caffeine would raise their blood pressure, even if what they were
drinking was entirely caffeine free.The sooner you recognize the power of your thoughts,
the sooner you will be able to wield them and improve your quality of life.
The stories we tell ourselves about who we are go a long way to shape our reality. For
example, if you tell yourself that you are socially awkward, when you go to an event,
you’re more likely to keep your distance, hide away, avoid actively talking to people.
What will happen? You won’t make new connections, and you’ll have proven to yourself that
you definitely have problems in social situations. You can start by listing the labels you’ve
given yourself. Maybe you think you’re no good with money. Perhaps you think you’ll
never find love. Once you’ve listed out all the things you
currently believe, take a moment to reflect on the fact that just because you think something,
doesn’t mean that it is an objective truth. You can always change your thoughts. To do
so, write an opposing belief in front of the labels you have given yourself. Your opposing
beliefs could be something like I am actively learning to be better with my money, or, I
deserve love. Now think of ways in which you can test the truth of these new, empowering
beliefs. If you think you are undeserving of love, do something which will help you
feel deserving. Self-love is equally valid and if you show love to yourself, you make
it easier for others to love you as well. Sign up for some budgeting classes to help
you develop healthier habits surrounding money. If you think that your life will never change,
you’re right - it won’t. So take this opportunity to step outside of your comfort
zone and see what happens when you start changing the way you think and act accordingly. The
more you make a conscious decision to always focus on the positive potential in any given
moment and seek out the lessons life has to offer you, you’ll find yourself becoming
less stressed and experiencing true inner peace.
We at Philosophies for Life, wish you a very happy new year. May this new year bring new
happiness, new achievements, and a lot of new inspiration in your life. In this new
year if you wish to get started with the habit of reading or if you wish to read more on
stoicism, then we definitely recommend you this book called Stoicism: How to Use Stoic
Philosophy to Find Inner Peace and Happiness by Jason Hemlock. Inspired by the wisdom of
ancient philosophers such as Marcus Aurelius, this book brings this powerful philosophy
to the modern world with practical exercises which might transform your world. Click on
the link in the description to get your copy and if you enjoyed this video, please do make
sure to check out our full philosophies for life playlist and for more videos to help
you find success and happiness using ancient philosophical wisdom, don’t forget to subscribe.
Thanks so much for watching.
